headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: Gross Domestic Product
summary: See overall percent change in GDP from preceding quarters, and GDP components.

headline: Charting the Debt Debate
summary: See Journal graphics on the debt-ceiling and deficit fight.

headline: AMERIGROUP, TeleNav: Biggest Price Decliners (AGP, TNAV)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Decliners.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of July 29, 2011

headline: Sale of $51 Billion in Short-Term Bills Set
summary: The Treasury plans to sell $51 billion Monday in short-term bills, divided between $27 billion 13-week and $24 billion 26-week bills.

headline: Antwerp: All Dressed Up With Someplace to Go
summary: The Belgian city of Antwerp has a surprisingly oversized style footprint. But the creative spirit that pervades the city blends beautifully with its traditions, and is accessible to almost anyone.

headline: Photos of the Day: July 29
summary: In today's photos, a girl attends the Vintage Festival in London, a boy tends to his family's camels in Kenya, fans line up at a Hong Kong comic and animation festival and more.

headline: Building Momentum
summary: A new exhibit at the Princeton University Art Museum shows how photographers have traced and documented the life span of buildings, from construction to decay and demolition.

headline: U.S. Safety Board to Assist Asiana Crash Probe
summary: The crash of an Asiana Airlines cargo plane with a suspected fire in its hold has attracted the attention of U.S. government safety experts, regulators and industry officials.

headline: Army Corps Begins to Reduce Releases From Missouri River Dams
summary: The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers said it would begin gradually reducing record-shattering releases from its six Missouri River dams this weekend, following heavy rains and snowmelt in the spring.

headline: US Airways Sues Pilots Union Over Flight Delays
summary: US Airways sued its pilots union to block what the company alleges is an illegal job-action causing flight delays and intimidating pilots.

headline: Colombia Lifts Key Bank Rate
summary: Colombia's central bank increased interest rates for the sixth-straight month, citing the need for higher borrowing costs to control inflation and higher-than-forecast economic growth.

headline: New Medical-Device Rules Sought
summary: A panel called for an overhaul in medical-device regulation, saying the FDA should give more intense scrutiny to a broad class of devices that currently receive only an abbreviated review.

headline: Obama Unveils Fuel-Economy Changes
summary: President Obama unveiled an agreement with major auto makers to lift the average fuel economy of new cars to 54.5 miles a gallon by 2025, roughly double the current level, in a bid to reduce U.S. oil consumption.

headline: John Turturro in Character
summary: Actor and director John Turturro has portrayed characters from a dimwitted convict to a creepy bowler over his years in show business. Here are some highlights from his career.

headline: Ripping the Old Model to Shreds
summary: A day behind the wheel of the CLS63 AMG equals the Gross National Happiness of Bhutan, but the realities of physics render it also just a little bit spooky.

headline: Market Eyes Chance for Small Caps to Jump
summary: Traders saw heavy action in bullish contracts that profit in the event that one of the market's more volatile sectors begins to rise. The moves targeted the iShares Russell 2000 Index Fund, which tracks small-cap stocks.

headline: Pricing Firms Brace for Downgrade
summary: Securities-pricing services used by mutual funds and others to set daily values for municipal bonds are telling clients that they are prepared to handle the fallout from any downgrade of U.S. debt.

headline: Fashion: The Mid-Length Skirt
summary: Right now, the skirt's new sweet spot falls just below the knee, writes the Journal's Alexa Brazilian. "It transitions perfectly from late summer into early fall," she writes. Here are some looks from 2011 Fall Fashion runways.

headline: Escondida Workers Reject Bonus Offer; Copper Strike Continues
summary: Unionized workers at Chilean copper mine Escondida on Friday rejected the company's offer of a bonus and the strike at the mine continues.

headline: GOL Linhas Aereas Inteligentes, TeleNav: Biggest Price Decliners (GOL, TNAV)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Decliners.

headline: Regal Entertainment Group, Allied Healthcare International: Biggest Price Gainers (RGC, AHCI)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

headline: General Electric, Vanguard Total Bond Market: Money Flow Leaders (GE, BND)
summary: Markets Data Center: Money Flow Leaders.

headline: Genworth Plans for Possible Split
summary: Genworth Financial is taking steps to prepare for a possible split of the company, CEO Michael Fraizer said. He said the insurer was also moving up its plan to reinstate share buybacks.

headline: New Standards to Change Cars
summary: U.S. fuel economy standards would double by 2025 under a new deal the White House announced this week with auto makers and environmentalists. Take a look at some of the different technologies auto makers may use to improve fuel economy and meet the new requirements.

headline: C&J Energy Rises in Debut
summary: Oil and gas well service specialist C&J Energy Services closed out a busy week in the U.S. IPO market, making modest gains.

headline: Oil Falls 1.8% as Market Braces for U.S. Demand Hit
summary: Light, sweet crude-oil futures tumbled amid concerns about slower-than-expected U.S. economic growth and as the debt-ceiling standoff in Washington remained unresolved going into the weekend.

headline: Ultraconservative Muslims Join Egypt Protest
summary: Ultraconservative Muslims turned out in force Friday as tens of thousands filled Cairo's central Tahrir Square in a rally marked by a growing rift in the protest movement.

headline: Buying a Home that Floats
summary: This home isn't underwater—it's on the water. Should the reader buy it?

headline: Tracking The Market's 'Fear' Gauges
summary: Financial markets are growing increasingly nervous about the threat of a downgrade of the U.S.'s credit rating or, worse, a default. But a look at the market's various "fear" gauges suggest few market participants are truly panicking.

headline: T-Bills Show Signs of Jitters as Default Deadline Gets Closer
summary: The traditionally mundane short-end Treasurys market is selling off sharply as the prospect of a U.S. default rises, showing the market is worrying about the debt impasse even though longer-term notes are enjoying safe-haven buying.

headline: Key Dollar Libor Rises
summary: The cost of borrowing dollars for three months in the London interbank market continued to climb on worries that some European banks were finding it hard to access dollars amid the debt crisis.

headline: Cognizant to Buy CoreLogic India Unit
summary: Cognizant Technology Solutions has agreed to acquire the India-based captive operations of CoreLogic in a cash deal valued at roughly $50 million, further expanding its footprint in the nation.

headline: New York Photos of the Week: July 25-29
summary: A martial artist demonstrates a trick in Battery Park, garbage bags keep a Bronx resident's feet dry, kids show off their game faces in tug-of-war, and more in this week's best photos from across Greater New York.

headline: A Private Pool in a Hong Kong High Rise
summary: Premium flats at the Imperial Cullinan, a new group of high-rises in Hong Kong's Tsim Sha Tsui neighborhood, feature Italian marble, Miele appliances and for two "Imperial Sky Manor" residents, private swimming pools.

headline: Panel Scorns Nuclear-Waste Policy
summary: A presidential panel scolded the U.S. government for failing to effectively deal with a growing stockpile of radioactive nuclear waste, saying Washington should create a new, independent entity to decide where to dump it.

headline: Crash Probe Turns to Pilot Training
summary: French crash investigators recommended that safety authorities re-examine pilot training, as they issued a report on the final moments of a 2009 crash of an Air France jet into the Atlantic Ocean.

headline: Union Pressures Verizon to Reach Contract Deal
summary: Workers at Verizon voted to let their union representatives call a strike if they can't reach a new contract agreement with the telecommunications company.

headline: Obama Urges Deficit Compromise
summary: Obama said Democrats and Republicans are not "miles apart" on a deficit-reduction pact and urged Congress to compromise just days ahead of a potential U.S. default and credit-rating cut.

headline: Asia Stocks Decline
summary: Asian markets ended lower on a setback to expectations for progress in resolving the U.S. debt crisis, with Japanese stocks also hit by a set of weak earnings reports and profit outlooks.

headline: Poor Month for European Stocks
summary: The Stoxx Europe 600 ended July with another loss, bringing the decline for the month to 2.8%. The CAC 40's 7.8% slump for July was its worst monthly showing since May 2010.

headline: A Tale of Two Messis
summary: Argentina's stunning exit from the Copa America renewed a question that's haunted the world's best player: Why does Lionel Messi's club team, Barcelona, flourish while his home country underachieves?

headline: NATO Takes Control of Kosovo Crossings
summary: American and French peacekeepers took control of two customs posts on Kosovo's northern border with Serbia after they were attacked by Serbs armed with firebombs.

headline: Canada Economy Unexpectedly Soft in May
summary: Canada's economy was surprisingly weak in May, pointing to an even softer-than-expected second quarter. With the outlook clouded by the U.S. debt crisis, economists say it's unlikely the central bank will raise rates in September.

headline: Samsung Stops Reporting Phone Sales Data
summary: Samsung Electronics said it would stop disclosing sales figures and forecasts for its mobile phones and tablet computers, a step it attributed to business risks and that analysts said was probably due to its legal battle with Apple.

headline: Who's Afraid of Rick Perry?
summary: A new Gallup poll suggests that a possible entry into the GOP presidential primary by the Texas governor should concern frontrunners.

headline: Google Buys IBM Patents
summary: Google said it has purchased technology patents from IBM in an effort to shield itself against lawsuits.

headline: Colfax, Allied Healthcare International: Biggest Price Gainers (CFX, AHCI)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

headline: Microsoft, Vanguard Total Bond Market: Money Flow Leaders (MSFT, BND)
summary: Markets Data Center: Money Flow Leaders.

headline: Financing Near for Major New York Condo-Hotel Tower
summary: Developer Extell is close to getting a $700 million construction loan on the 57th Street project, sources say.

headline: Moody's Puts Spain on Downgrade Review
summary: Moody's put Spain's Aa2 ratings on review for possible downgrade, saying the euro zone's fourth-largest economy faces rising contagion risks.

headline: BSkyB in Share Buyback
summary: British Sky Broadcasting Group said that it will return $1.23 billion to shareholders, as the company's board gave its unanimous support to Chairman James Murdoch.

headline: Rosneft Shares Fall As Profits Disappoint
summary: Shares in Rosneft, Russia's largest oil producer, fell as the company reported a rise in second-quarter net profit that was below analysts' expectations.

headline: Asia Helps Luxury Brands Sparkle
summary: Luxury continued to shine in the first half of the year as purveyors of pricey handbags, jewelry and clothes announced bumper results while remaining upbeat about the coming months, a trend which underscores the sector's ability to ride out economic woes.

headline: Spain's Next Bond-Market Test
summary: Spain is likely to face higher funding costs when it sells bonds on Thursday. Its benchmark 10-year yield, already above 6%, again rose sharply.

headline: Treasury, Fed Officials to Meet With Bankers
summary: Officials from the Treasury Department and Federal Reserve Bank of New York are expected to meet with roughly 20 banks and primary dealers on Friday to talk about a major bond sale expected next week, even if Congress doesn't raise the debt ceiling.

headline: SAIL Profit Drops 29%
summary: State-run Steel Authority of India said its net profit for the first quarter fell 29% as rising production costs offset higher sales.

headline: Robot Olympics Kick Off in China
summary: The second International Humanoid Robot Olympics kicked off in China, attracting 22 teams from six countries and regions.

headline: India Court Orders Mining Halt in Iron-Ore Hub
summary: India's Supreme Court has ordered a halt to all mining in the Bellary district of the country's southern Karnataka state to prevent environmental degradation, people involved in the matter said.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid's Earnings Rise 13%
summary: Newell Rubbermaid's second-quarter earnings rose 13%, helped by fewer restructuring costs, but margins fell as price increases couldn't offset rising commodity costs.

headline: AllianceBernstein Profit Rises 11%
summary: AllianceBernstein Holding's second-quarter earnings rose 11% as the fund manager reported higher revenue, though operating margins and research-services revenue fell.

headline: ICICI Bank Net Profit Up 30%
summary: ICICI Bank, India's largest private-sector lender by assets, posted a 30% jump in first-quarter net profit, boosted by strong fund demand from companies and lower provisions for bad loans.

headline: BofA Merrill Global Equities Co-Head Going to UBS
summary: Bank of America Merrill Lynch's Mike Stewart is leaving the bank, two months after it said a new co-head of global securities would join the firm this summer. He will move to UBS, where he will be co-head of global equities.

headline: MetLife Expects Excess Capital
summary: Executives at MetLife said they expected to have $4.8 billion in excess capital by year end. The funds could be used to pay dividends, buy back shares, repurchase debt or make acquisitions.

headline: Idea Cellular Profit Falls 12%
summary: Idea Cellular reported a lower-than-expected 12% fall in first-quarter net profit, as stable call tariffs and increased mobile traffic partly offset higher interest costs and amortization expenses.

headline: JSW Says Karnataka Iron-Ore Dealings Legal
summary: JSW Steel said its iron-ore purchasing and other transactions in the southern Indian state of Karnataka were done legally, refuting allegations made by an anti-corruption ombudsman.

headline: SEBI Tinkers With the Takeover Code
summary: The Securities and Exchange Board of India's amendment to India's takeover regulations this week doesn't move the needle much, writes Samita Sawardekar.

headline: Euro-Zone Inflation Falls
summary: The annual rate of inflation in the 17 countries that share the euro fell unexpectedly in July, although it remained above the European Central Bank target.

headline: French Banks Tally Greek Costs
summary: French banks and insurers lost around $4.23 billion in the second quarter because of the recently announced Greek rescue plan, indicating that the deal will hit their earnings but won't damage them severely.

headline: BMW Shows Off Electric Concept Cars
summary: BMW presented two concept cars for the first generation of electric vehicles to be launched under its new sub-brand i.

headline: India Shares Edge Lower
summary: Indian shares closed slightly lower in volatile trade, tracking weak global markets, but losses were limited by an advance in ICICI Bank on the back of robust quarterly results.

headline: Bond Trading Weighs on Japan's Big Banks
summary: A falloff in once-robust bond trading profits weighed on Japan's top three banks in the April-June quarter with Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group Inc. being the lone megabank to report net profit gains, largely due to a one-off factor.

headline: Japanese Yields Rise
summary: Japanese government bond yields rose Friday as investors bet on a weekend solution to the U.S. debt ceiling, which would make the safe-haven assets less attractive.

headline: IAG Swings to Profit
summary: International Consolidated Airlines Group, the company formed through the merger of British Airways and Spain's Iberia, returned to a profit based on the strength of its U.K. operations.

headline: Emerging Europe: Week in Photos
summary: See a roundup of the week's best photos, from an elephant escaping during a commercial shooting, Poland submerged in heavy rains and Formula One drivers prepare for the Hungarian Grand Prix.

headline: TVS Motor Profit Rises 46%
summary: TVS Motor beat market estimates with a 46% jump in its first-quarter net profit, aided by higher sales of two- and three-wheelers, which helped the auto maker outweigh a rise in the cost of inputs such as steel and aluminum.

headline: HTC Aims to Reassure Investors Amid Apple Row
summary: Taiwanese smartphone maker HTC said it expects third-quarter revenue to grow 80%, and its chief executive is confident its lawsuit with Apple won't hurt business.

headline: U.K. House Prices Edge Up
summary: U.K. house prices edged higher in July and new mortgage approvals were at their highest for more than a year in June, data showed, but economists doubt a housing market recovery is underway.

headline: Spanish Unemployment Eases From 14-Year High
summary: Spain's economy added 151,400 jobs in the second-quarter as a result of a surge in hiring for the country's busy holiday season, data released Friday by the country's statistics agency INE showed.

headline: Weyerhaeuser Profit Slides 29%
summary: Weyerhaeuser's second-quarter profit fell 29% as the forest-products company's revenue and profit margins came under pressure.

headline: Japanese Drug Makers Post Contrasting Results
summary: Japanese drug makers reported mixed fiscal first-quarter earnings, with Takeda Pharmaceutical posting 18% growth in net profit on sales of new treatments while rival Daiichi Sankyo saw a 24% profit drop on the weak performance of its Indian unit.

headline: Portugal's PM Says Bailout On Track
summary: Portugal's government said it is on track to meet deadlines for budget cuts and structural reforms under the $111.78 billion bailout deal the country has received.

headline: Shiseido Nearly Breaks Even
summary: Japan's biggest cosmetics maker by revenue said that while sales grew about 8%, it booked a net loss of $3.6 million, citing a deferred tax adjustment.

headline: Nuclear Output Powers EDF
summary: French state-controlled power behemoth Électricité de France posted a 54% increase in first-half net profit, boosted by higher nuclear output.

headline: DoCoMo Sees Net Profit Rise 12%
summary: Japan's biggest mobile carrier by subscriber numbers said an increase in smartphone users boosted lucrative data traffic.

headline: Hong Kong Taps New Head of Securities Agency
summary: The Hong Kong government plans to name lawyer Ashley Alder as the new head of the city's securities watchdog, filling a position critical for the regulation of China's capital markets.

headline: ANA Loss Widens After Quake
summary: All Nippon Airways reported a wider net loss for the April-June quarter, as domestic and international passenger numbers slumped in the period immediately after the March 11 earthquake.

headline: GTL: No Formal Talks With Viom on Stake Sale
summary: GTL Infrastructure said it isn't involved in any formal discussions with India's Viom Networks for a sale of assets or a partnership.

headline: Mazda Motor Net Loss Widens
summary: Mazda Motor said the yen's appreciation and the March 11 disaster are taking a heavy toll on the car maker's domestic production, which depends greatly on exports to maintain output levels.

headline: Hermès Hits Mumbai
summary: French luxury brand Hermès has opened its third store in India, this time on the streets of Mumbai. A peek inside the newly opened store, in pictures.

headline: Hang Lung Profit Drops 75% As Housing Slows
summary: Property developer Hang Lung Properties reported a 75% drop in fiscal-year profit as it refrained from launching completed residential projects in Hong Kong while the government moved to contain surging home prices.

headline: EADS Hit By Currency Swings
summary: Franco-German aerospace giant European Aeronautic Defence & Space Co. said its first-half net profit fell 41% as accounting revaluations due to a stronger euro more than offset rising orders.

headline: Life Insurance Growth Bolsters AIA Results
summary: Asian insurance giant AIA Group reported better-than-expected fiscal first-half results were lifted by the strong performance of its life insurance business, which the company expects to continue to grow.

headline: Total Hit by Weaker Production
summary: French oil major Total posted a 12% drop in second-quarter net profit as higher crude oil prices and the integration of Novatek's production failed to offset lower overall output and weaker refining margins.

headline: Eni's Net Falls on Libyan Cutbacks
summary: Eni said second-quarter net profit dropped 31% from a year earlier despite higher crude prices, as hydrocarbon production fell because of a curtailment in its Libyan operations.

headline: SNB Posts Loss of $10.8 Billion
summary: The Swiss National Bank is likely to come under renewed public criticism after reporting another hefty book loss owing to the franc's sharp appreciation against all major currencies.

headline: German Retail Sales Beat Expectations
summary: German seasonally adjusted retail sales rose 6.3% from a month earlier in June, well above analysts' expectations for a 1.7% increase.

headline: Pearson Raises Profit Forecast
summary: Pearson raised its 2011 earnings forecast and dividend, citing a stronger performance in digital businesses and developing markets despite a decline in its net profit.

headline: India in Pictures
summary: A girl dries strands of jute fiber, India fails to qualify for the 2014 FIFA World Cup, Bangalore Fashion Week, and more.

headline: McConnell Endorses Boehner Proposal
summary: Top Senate Republican McConnell embraced a plan by House Speaker Boehner to raise the U.S. borrowing limit in two steps, lending support amid opposition by conservatives.

headline: Hitachi Profit Drops 97%
summary: Hitachi's net profit tumbled 97% in the three months through June as the lingering impact from the March 11 earthquake and tsunami hurt domestic production.

headline: Japanese Officials Watching for Excessive Yen Moves
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Yoshihiko Noda said the authorities will act in the currency market if yen movement becomes excessive, rather than acting if it hits any particular level.

headline: Kia Net Soars 67%
summary: Kia Motors, South Korea's second-largest car maker by sales, said its second-quarter net profit surged 67% on robust sales in the U.S. and higher prices that outpaced the U.S. dollar's decline against the won.

headline: China Regulator: Banks Can Take Property Hit
summary: Chinese banks can withstand a 50% decline in property prices, the chairman of the country's banking regulator said, citing the results of the latest stress tests.

headline: Dell Launches China-Only Tablet
summary: Dell Inc. started selling a 10-inch tablet computer that it will offer only in China and that runs Google's Android operating system, expanding its push into a product category dominated by Apple's iPad.

headline: Asia in Pictures
summary: Cooling off in the Water Cube in Beijing, Indonesian football fans celebrate a victory in Jakarta, soldiers restore an apartment damaged by a landslide in Seoul, and more.

headline: Trial for Norway Gunman May Begin in 2012
summary: Anders Behring Breivik, who has admitted to being behind the Norway massacre that killed 76 people, may be brought to trial in 2012, the head of the Norwegian prosecuting authority said.

headline: Taiwan Says Arms Deals Will Get Harder
summary: Taiwan President Ma Ying-jeou said debt problems in the U.S. and Europe could slow global economic growth in the second half of this year.

headline: Samsung Electronics Profit Falls
summary: Samsung Electronics said its second-quarter profit fell 18% amid weak demand and lower prices for consumer electronics broadly, though smartphone sales led its cellphone business to more than double in profitability.

headline: Hong Kong Plans to Name New Securities Regulator
summary: The Hong Kong government plans to name lawyer Ashley Alder as the new head of the city's securities regulator, with an announcement expected early next week.

headline: Swire Pacific to Sell Property for $2.41 Billion
summary: Swire Pacific said its property arm plans to sell Festival Walk, a Hong Kong shopping and commercial complex, to Singapore-based Mapletree Investment Pte. Ltd. for $2.41 billion, in a move analysts said is aimed at raising funds to support the company's property expansion plans in China.

headline: Financial Briefing Book: July 29
summary: FINANCIAL BRIEFING BOOK: July 29

headline: Private Island Living
summary: The Exuma Cays, a string of islands off the coast of Florida, are attracting entertainers and CEOs with their sandy beaches, turquoise waters and remote location. Tour some of the islands and also look at others around the world priced below $1 million.

headline: China's HNA in Talks to Buy GE Container Venture
summary: Chinese company HNA Group is in exclusive negotiations to acquire GE SeaCo, a shipping container lessor co-owned by General Electric, in a deal that could be worth as much as $1 billion.

headline: Europe Turns Up
summary: Europe's main stock index ended a three-session losing streak, recovering from early losses as a bounce by Wall Street helped offset poorly received earnings. Most Asian stock markets ended lower.

headline: 'Laws So Voluminous That They Cannot Be Read'
summary: Our society has become more complex, and so too have the criminal statutes on the books ("As Criminal Laws Proliferate, More Are Ensnared," page one, July 23).

headline: Deluxe San Francisco Penthouse to Relist for 50% Off
summary: A penthouse apartment in San Francisco that was previously on the market for $70 million is now under new ownership and back on the market for $35 million.

headline: Is Beltran the Cadillac of Rentals?
summary: The Giants' acquisition of Carlos Beltran is a classic "rental"—a talented free-agent-to-be acquired for an all-in World Series push.

headline: Detroit Mayor Scales Back Overhaul
summary: Mayor Dave Bing unveiled the first concrete steps in his campaign to bolster Detroit's most viable neighborhoods, but it isn't as sweeping as he had discussed.

headline: A Display of Lalique's Beauty
summary: In the Alsatian village of Wingen-sur-Moder, where René Lalique built his glass factory in 1919, sits the recently opened Musée Lalique, which beautifully displays some 500 pieces of the artist's jewelry, glassware and crystal.

headline: What's on Around Europe
summary: The Weekend Journal's guide to exhibitions, concerts and events across Europe.

headline: Bribe Charges Filed Against Food Worker
summary: A restaurant owner who allegedly offered an undercover city investigator $500 to overlook violations during an inspection was arrested on bribery charges.

headline: A Special Delivery for Food Charity
summary: Bruce Nelson wanted his recent gift of about $100,000 God's Love We Deliver, an organization that provides meals to people with severe or life-altering illnesses, to be personal and so he directed it toward the new refrigerated van and two large walk-in freezers.

headline: Sprint Loses More Contract Customers
summary: Sprint Nextel reported a wider loss in the second quarter and lost more contract customers than expected as it faced heightened competition from its rivals who carry the Apple iPhone.

headline: Bob Bradley Is Out As U.S. Soccer Coach
summary: Bob Bradley is out as coach of the U.S. men's soccer team. Plus, the Schleck brothers will have a chance for revenge against Tour de France winner Cadel Evans next month at the U.S. Pro Cycling Challenge.

headline: Libyan Rebel's Death Dims Advances
summary: A top Libyan rebel commander was shot and killed by unknown assailants, just hours after he had been detained for questioning by the rebel leadership, threatening to plunge the rebel ranks into chaos and infighting.

headline: Imitation of Art
summary: Works of art at the Las Vegas county government building make subtle jabs at the artwork on display at CityCenter, a $9 billion luxury residence, hotel and shopping mall on the Las Vegas Strip.

headline: From Wall Street to Crawl Street
summary: While investors still hanker for the days of 20%-plus returns on equity, trading operations are turning in far more pedestrian results.

headline: Love, Fresh and New
summary: Shakespeare & Company's production of "Romeo and Juliet" will make you feel like you've been touched for the very first time.

headline: Profits to Be Milked at Danone
summary: Commodity inflation at the French dairy company exceeded 10% in the first half, but it should be better equipped to withstand the chill this time around.

headline: Come Fly the Union Skies
summary: Ray LaHood shuts down the FAA to preserve a Big Labor advantage.

headline: Coffee Boosts Honduras Economy
summary: The rise of Honduras as a top producer of coffee has given the impoverished country a strong economic boost.

headline: Court Orders BT to Block Pirate Site
summary: The U.K. High Court ordered telecommunications firm BT Group to block access to a pirate website following legal action by an association representing six major movie studios.

headline: Madoff Trustee Gets $1 Billion Settlement
summary: The court-appointed trustee recovering money for investors swindled by Bernard Madoff reached a settlement of more than $1 billion with Tremont Group Holdings, one of the largest funds that allegedly channeled money into his Ponzi scheme.

headline: Path Cleared in Dakota Case
summary: A state judge has allowed a racial discrimination suit by hedge fund manager Alphonse Fletcher Jr. to proceed against the Dakota, the famous co-op on Central Park West.

headline: A Beach Party Without the Elements
summary: At the Dream Downtown hotel, some partygoers looked beach-ready; others looked as if they came from work. Few wore the DKNY sunglasses they had picked up.

headline: Bahrain's Opposition Says Reform Offer Falls Short
summary: Delegates to Bahrain's so-called national dialogue recommended a package of modest political reforms on Thursday that failed to meet key demands of the country's opposition, an outcome that is likely to keep tensions high in the Persian Gulf state.

headline: India Minister Exits as Graft Fight Mounts
summary: Corruption took center stage in Indian politics as the ruling party paved the way for an antigraft bill to be considered by Parliament and the main opposition party ousted a state chief minister over corruption allegations.

headline: How Test Cricket Can Be Saved
summary: With little effort, the popularity of the England-India series doesn't have to be the exception for Test cricket.

headline: Art and Economics in Berlin
summary: Berlin has become a major contemporary art center, but contemporary art is hardly at the center of Berlin life.

headline: Newport Swings Again
summary: Sales are up at the iconic folk and jazz festivals, where music stars don't mind a pay cut.

headline: Retail Pact for World Trade Center
summary: Mall operator Westfield Group has struck a $612 million deal to develop shops and restaurants in and around the World Trade Center site.

headline: Privacy Means Control, Not Secrecy
summary: Regarding Gordon Crovitz's "The Right to Privacy from Brandeis to Flickr" (Information Age, July 25): As the privacy commissioner of Ontario, Canada, I couldn't agree more with Mr. Crovitz that privacy is all about control and individual choice.

headline: Little to Smile About With Growth Outlook
summary: As the government continues to grapple with the debt ceiling, the U.S. economy doesn't have much wiggle room, writes Kelly Evans.

headline: India Changes Takeover Code
summary: India's capital markets regulator raised the threshold that triggers an open offer to 25% from 15% and enhanced the minimum offer size in steps, in an attempt to encourage mergers and acquisitions in one of the world's fastest growing economies.

headline: T-Bills on the Brink
summary: As gridlock continues in Washington, many in the market are scrambling to figure out which debt would be most in danger of defaulting. A top candidate: The Treasury bill that matures Aug. 4.

headline: Strassel: Boehner's Moment of Truth
summary: The speaker has positioned his party to take credit for a bill that averts a crisis.

headline: In Las Vegas, Art Imitates Art
summary: The opulent CityCenter has a piece by Maya Lin depicting the Colorado River in silver. A few miles away, "CountyCenter" boasts a replica in chicken wire and aluminum honoring a sewage channel.

headline: New Learjet...Now Mexican Made
summary: Mexico is attracting aerospace companies from the U.S. and Europe. Among them is Bombardier, which is building its newest corporate jet, the Learjet 85, in Querétaro.
